abstracts.cdata!:
This Geothermal Energy Development
            Program (Geofund) Project for Europe and Central Asia
            systematically promotes the use of geothermal energy by
            removing barriers and reducing the global emissions of
            greenhouse gases. This safeguards section of the operational
            manual assesses negative environmental impacts and lists
            suggestions for mitigating them. Among the risks considered
            are these: The land requirement will lead to vegetal loss
            soil, soil erosion, landslides, ad land ownership issues.
            These could be mitigated by using single drill pads (several
            wells), revegetating, and providing adequate land
            compensation. Taking water for drilling may lead to local
            watershed impacts, and damming and diverting local streams.
            These effects could be alleviated by taking water from
            streams with high flow rates, coinciding drilling with the
            rainy season, building temporary reservoirs, and liaising
            with local farmers to consider their usage. Taking water
            from reservoirs may result in hydrothermal eruptions,
            lowering of the water table, an increase in the steam zone,
            and saline intrusion. To offset these effects, avoid areas
            where there's a propensity for hydrothermal eruptions
            and carefully manage resources. To prevent effects from
            waste disposal into streams and waterways, treat effluent
            and remove undesired constituents, reinject all waste
            fluids, use a cascaded approach towards waste fluids, and
            dilute brine. Also when reinjecting, plan carefully and
            monitor flow patterns before re-injecting. Minimize air
            emissions by scrubbing hydrogen disulfide and treating other
            non-condensable gases. Reduce nose with mufflers and silencers.
